newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Tech stocks take the spotlight.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Tech stocks take the spotlight.

text.p: Options on technology stocks drew heavy interest on Friday as the stocks helped fuel a dazzling broad stock market rally, traders said.
As the tech stocks rallied, so did the tech stock indices. The tech-heavy Nasdaq composite index was ahead 19 points, or 1.65 percent, at 1,185 by 1230 CDT (1730 GMT).
"The tech indices are way up," said Harrison Roth, a first vice president at Cowen & Co, noting that there are nine technology stock indices.
Options on blue chip International Business Machines Corp were among the most active around as the stock surged.
IBM shares, helped by an upgraded near term rating by Merrill Lynch, rallied 5-1/4 to 122-1/2 on nearly four million shares. The stock hit an intraday high of 122-7/8.
Traders said investors were buying a lot of the IBM calls but some were also writing calls, probably against long stock positions.
The IBM September 120 call was the most active, with 6,263 contracts changing hands. The option, with open interest through Thursday of 6,600, was up 2-5/8 at 3-3/8.
The October 120 call traded 3,766 contracts, compared with an open interest of 12,692. It gained 2-7/8 to six.
On the put side, the IBM September 120 traded more than 3,600 contracts. Its open interest, including an addition of 1,246 on Thursday, was 2,169. The option fell 2-11/16 to 13/16.
Other active puts included the September 115 and the October 115 and 120s.
Buying was seen in IBM calls all the way out to April 1997, where more than 500 contracts of the April 125 traded. The option rose 2-5/8 to 10-5/8.
Options on shares of Oracle Corp were also among the most active.
Oracle shares were ahead 3-3/8 at 40-7/8 on heavy turnover.

"They announced earnings that were in line" with expectations, an Oracle options trader said. "The first quarter is usually slow and they met estimates, which was a fairly bullish indication on the rest of the year for them."
He said most of the options activity was from investors closing out speculative or insurance positions they held going into the earnings report.
Despite the stock's rally, the busiest Oracle option was the September 40 put, which traded more than 5,400 contracts. It was down 2-9/16 at 7/16 and had reached a low of 1/4.
One trader said investors were most likely getting out of those positions "before (the option) goes to zero."
But the corresponding call traded a heavy 3,670 contracts, suggesting that some investors had crossed a straddle.
Marty Kearney at PTI Securities noted that volatilities on the September 40 puts and calls remained low.

Other actives included the September 35 put which traded 3,900 contracts, the October 40 call with 1,350 contracts traded, and the January 1997 45 call with about 1,300 contracts traded. --G.Crawford, (312) 408-8750/E-mail: derivatives@reuters.com
